stream_context.summary: Kaze works on the Oil-Rig course of Return to Yoshi’s Island.  The session focuses on (1) refining the RTYI engine with data from the Only Up 64 play-test, (2) implementing a cement-ruining mechanic and a crying “Builder Koopa” Easter egg, (3) designing/rigging the Wiggler overseer NPC, and (4) touching up physics, camera and warp behaviour.

development_findings.summary: Only Up 64 public play-test data will be fed back into RTYI, and Kaze plans “one or two more hacks on the RTYI engine” before the final release.
development_findings.quote: Only Up 64 was really useful play-test data and I'm gonna use the play-test data to improve RTYI – we should make like one or two more hacks on the RTYI engine before RTYI is released.

development_findings.summary: Outer-rotate force lowered and several physics constants tweaked; ceiling dives now cause an immediate bonk unless the player’s direction matches the ceiling slope.
development_findings.quote: I reduced the outer rotate force and I changed a lot of the physics and I think they're working a lot better now.

development_findings.summary: Memory-leak source identified as “too many condition triangles” in collision data and is being pruned.
development_findings.quote: What's leaking memory? Too many condition triangles.

development_findings.summary: Warp behaviour will be rebuilt so Mario keeps his current action while inputs are ‘held’ through the transition, avoiding awkward pauses at 60 fps.
development_findings.quote: Instead what's it's gonna be is that the inputs are just gonna be held … Mario's normal actions are just gonna continue while the warp is happening.

development_findings.summary: Input-lag complaints traced to players switching between 60 fps emulation and 30 fps N64; a full 60 fps physics rewrite deemed impractical.
development_findings.quote: Yes, but I would also have to rewrite all of Mario's physics to be in 60fps – not really a very reasonable thing to do.

development_findings.summary: A dirtiness-meter for Builder Koopa’s cement was implemented by sampling 93 texture pixels per frame instead of scanning all 16,384, cutting the computation to ~1⁄15.
development_findings.quote: We just cut computation costs into like basically a fifteenth.

development_findings.summary: Threshold-driven Easter egg: if ~95 % of the cement texture is darkened, Builder Koopa switches to a sobbing animation and new dialogue.
development_findings.quote: If you like basically make almost the entire area black, he's just gonna start crying and he's gonna have a new text.

development_findings.summary: All physics, camera, and other ‘magic numbers’ were moved into a single header of #defines with comments to make rapid iteration easier.
development_findings.quote: I decided I will make all the magic numbers into defines in this file and I even added comments that follow some sort of code guidelines.

development_findings.summary: Wiggler Overseer NPC design: starts calm, gains red tint and angry animations each time the player sabotages one of four workers, then runs off the rig and despawns after the final trigger.
development_findings.quote: You go to the next guy and you ruin his day … until eventually you messed with all four people … then he just disappears.

development_findings.summary: Back-face culling is enabled for certain effects on N64 hardware to avoid performance hits and visual noise; confirmed to run acceptably on console with this change.

context_findings.summary: Kaze recently moved to Canada, jokes about being ‘rich’, and complains that shipping Yu-Gi-Oh cards is nearly as expensive as the cards.
context_findings.quote: Now that I'm living in Canada and I'm rich and all I wanna get some Yu-Gi-Oh cards … shipping to Canada is almost as expensive as just buying the damn thing itself.

context_findings.summary: He abandoned Twitch because excessive ads ruined viewer experience and now streams exclusively on YouTube.
context_findings.quote: Twitch is just so many ads that I just don't like it anymore … I decided it is time to leave.

context_findings.summary: Kaze argues that many criticisms of RTYI’s physics stem from nostalgia for vanilla bugs, especially slope behaviour.
context_findings.quote: There's definitely a rose tinting with vanilla Mario 64 collision … a lot of people got upset at the slope jumps but like it's just Mario 64 for you.

context_findings.summary: He values optimisation over extensive commentary and historically delegated documentation to others.
context_findings.quote: You know how I don't comment my code? … I just got someone who doesn't know how it works and got them to write down everything I say.

context_findings.summary: Excited by early Super-Chat donations, he contemplates paying for Twitter Blue purely for ad-revenue potential, but dislikes the perceived stigma of the blue check.
context_findings.quote: You guys have no idea the shit I would do for $5 a month on Twitter ad revenue.

biobak.summary: Offers additional modeling help after gaining confidence and actively provides feedback on simplifying Wiggler feet, polygon counts, and mock-up concepts.
Supplies updated penguin model and discusses builder Koopa crying threshold and dirt-area suggestions.

zeina.summary: Assigned multiple animations: penguin idle flap, sitting/falling Goomba, and especially the crying/stomping Builder Koopa sequences.
zeina.quote: So you should give him a sobbing animation for that. Can you do that real quick? – I can try, yeah.

key_stories.title: Builder Koopa Crying Easter Egg
key_stories.summary: Players can ruin the wet cement near a construction Koopa; if the dirtiness surpasses ~95 %, the Koopa breaks down crying with new dialogue.
key_stories.challenge: Needed a performance-friendly way to track how much of a texture the player has darkened.
key_stories.process: Kaze sampled 93 equally spaced pixels instead of the full 16 k and set a dirtiness threshold, while Zeina created a looping sob animation.
key_stories.outcome: Feature works in-game and will reward observant or mischievous players with unique dialogue and animation.
key_stories.key_quote: We just cut computation costs into like basically a fifteenth.

key_stories.title: Designing the Wiggler Overseer
key_stories.summary: Level 11 features a Wiggler foreman who grows angrier and redder as the player sabotages four workers, finally abandoning the site.
key_stories.challenge: Visually communicating anger stages, avoiding unnecessary hit-boxes, and keeping polygon count N64-safe.
key_stories.process: Kaze scales model to ~80 %, experiments with upright stance and helmeted segments; Biobak supplies mock-ups; sad/angry textures and color-shift logic added.
key_stories.outcome: Core design finalised; further work scheduled next stream to add run-away cut-scene and polish animations.
key_stories.key_quote: You go to the next guy and you ruin his day … until eventually you messed with all four people and the Wiggler just says ‘okay I've had enough’ and disappears.

key_stories.title: Physics & Camera Iteration via Only Up 64 Feedback
key_stories.summary: Community tests of Only Up 64 revealed mixed feelings about new physics, prompting engine refinements.
key_stories.challenge: Balance new mechanics with player expectations and fix reported issues such as unexpected ceiling behaviour and camera discomfort.
key_stories.process: Lowered outer-rotate force, rewrote ceiling dive to bonk, began redefining warp handling, collected input-lag reports and analysed frame-rate causes.
key_stories.outcome: Physics feel ‘a lot better’ according to Kaze; additional adjustments to be validated in upcoming mini-projects before RTYI release.
key_stories.key_quote: I reduced the outer rotate force and I changed a lot of the physics and I think they're working a lot better now.
